reviewText:
The best VR experience at the moment ‚Äì very highly recommended to try out this free demo by VALVE
I remember the week Valve was showing on some Electronic Expos around the world their Head-Mounted-Display (long for HMD) HTC Vive with especially this great demo. I was watching all the videos on youtube and was hyped like crazy.

Not only me, every single person that tried it out was amazed and incredible flashed by the possibilities this so called room-scale and those controllers would promise in games if implemented like in the demo compilation.

We were starting to dream about Half-Life 3 in VR, even that we hadn‚Äôt any idea how to fix the walking nausea and we couldn‚Äôt care less about teleporting actually.

Valve definitely set the bar very high for independent developers when it comes to room scale with the Vive. And to be honest, until now (end of May 2016) I have not seen a single other Vive game that could compete with the experience The Lab provides, with the quality of the image they managed to achieve, the precision in controlling, even if the biggest problem of the Vive or Oculus is the very low & blurry resolution of the screen. Subsequent HMD generations will improve this certainly.

Back to The Lab, which might be the best selling reason for the HTC Vive and for VR in general. It is the perfect tech demo you use to show off to your friends & family, to any critic of your precious new device.

Detailed graphics, huge room scale, smart avoidance of blurry images and the best implementation of 3D-360 as well as the full functionality of the Vive controllers are key and shiny.

It shows in short tech demos everything we are actually waiting for in a full title. It is now up to Valve to follow-up on their promise. It is up to Valve to publish at least a handful of AAA titles with the same quality as The Lab in coming month. For not letting us down. Leaving us back behind with the desire for more. And to be even more existential, for keeping VR alive and not letting it die in a shortly as a hype with promise, but without any care for high quality follow-up.

We are waiting!

The Lab is a unique experience. It will blow your gaming mind and warms your tech heart. It is the perfect fixer into the unreal world of VR. But now we desire more. So please Valve don't let us down and don't leave software supply to shady VR profiteers that sell their tech demos for shameful high prices.

reviewText:
+ Impressive visual quality
+ Interesting blend of experiments to try
+ Secret Shop's dark fantasy settings is great
- Chaperon system in Robot Repair is misleading
- Not much lasting appeal

The Lab is definitley worth downloading. Most experiments stand on their own, while a few were forgetable. The highlights are Longbow and Robot Repair.

Longbow has you standing on top of a castle firing arrows at minions, in a similar vain to Space Pirate Trainer. The arrows fly straight and hitting targets is hard but satisfying. It's difficult to have proper form though, in comparison to real life. Really wanted to rest my draw hand on my cheek but failed. Can't seem to find a comfortable / consistent place to rest it. This is the 1 demo that keeps me coming back.

Robot Repair has excellent texture quality and the sense of scale got me stoked. Glados is HUGE. However the chaperon system is confusing. It sets you in a room I thought was mapped to the play area. Got too excited and ran into a wall... There is actually a teleprot system inside this tiny room, so you can blink next to the edge then the VR and Real rooms get out of sync.

Xortex has similar problems with room bounds. It has more involved / time based movements that makes it more frustrating. The only time you see chaperon is when your right next to a wall, which doesn't work with fast paced movements. If you have just barely enough play space, the walls are a constant concern. In contrast, Space Pirate Trainer does it right and always shows you the bounds via a textured floor. Here, I was scared to move fast, which is a shame because I like the game itself.

Just to be clear, room bounds were only a problem in The Lab, not other VR titles.

Edit: After more time with Longbow, I've gotten much better at aiming from cheek.
